nodes.bodyText:
[Sanity check]: This collection is consistent with the one in SnapshotTransaction after this PR. I need to validate that this is equivalent before, too.
Is there a way that we can force this coupling? I.e. what if someone in the future changes one of the collectors and not the other?

This is equivalent before (see javadoc of Maps#transformValues: it takes on properties of the previous map).
That said, in general, it is not wrong for these to be different types, as long as they satisfy the properties we need (here, mainly that a map can be looked up by value of byte[]) so they don't need to be coupled. The tests should fail pretty quickly if that property is broken (since they do perform lookups).

I'm convinced this is the same as before, but my concern is that someone depends on this being ordered (i.e. not just a lookup but also an ordering), and that this could be broken in a later PR.
Other comments make me less concerned about this.
I'd be fine with breaking someone on that - the API documentation (see Transaction) does not guarantee that behaviour.
If we wanted to guarantee that we'd probably return SortedMap as interface type as well
[Sanity check]: This code is semantically the same as the previous code, right? As far as I can tell, the main change in this class is the use of KeyedStream over Maps.transformEntries?

Ah, so the ordering actually comes from getRowsColumnRangeIterator. As mentioned elsewhere, is there any way we can be defensive and make sure that we always use a sorted collector? I guess tests would fail if you just used any random collector?
Reasonable - I suppose the fact that it is not a SortedMap makes anyone's reliance on the ordering a bit suspicious. And either way, so long as the tests catch this we should catch any regressions.
What happens if you call iterator2.next()?
NoSuchElementException - I've added a pair of false hasNext() calls after the value is read.

Is there a test somewhere in this class that checks the output is correctly ordered? If not, can we add one such test? Even if there is a test in SnapshotTransaction there should be one here too, to confirm that the ordering stays the same.
Yes (though it's a bit non-obvious to find): AbstractTransactionTest#testColumnRangePagingTransaction_batchingVisitable()
You added two tests for the SerializableTransaction, why only one here?
Also, similar comment as above - do we test for the right ordering of values read?

I changed two methods in SerializableTransaction but only one in SnapshotTransaction: getRowsColumnRangeIterator was already safely implemented in SnapshotTransaction but not in SerializableTransaction. That said I think I'll move the two in the AbSTT to the general AbTT, so this test shouldn't be needed any more.
In terms of value testing: yes - this is in the abstract transaction test.
